WORLD BANK Staff Working Paper No. 348 July 1979 PRIVATE DIRECT FOREIGN INVESTMENT IN DEVELOPING COUNTRIES: POLICY ISSUES FOR HOST AND HOME GOVERNMENTS AND FOR INTERNATIONAL INSTITUTIONS A Background Study for World Development Report, 1979 The paper discusses the changing characteristics of private direct foreign investment in developing countries in relation to home and host country policies. An overall view of the geographical and sectoral characteristics of private direct foreign investtent flows to developing countries introduces the paper. The response of the transnational corporations to the changing environment in developing countries is then discussed. The main body of the paper is concerned with policy issues for the developing countries that wish to attract private direct foreign investment and for the industrialized countries that are the principal source of such flows. The authors conclude that overall macro economic and sectoral policies are of overwhelming policy importance, but also explore incentive policies and some institutional issues. A discussion of the role of international institutions in the private investment environment concludes the paper. A statistical annex reviews the availability of data and provides a set of basic data, updating Working Paper No. 149.  PRIVATE DIRECT FOREIGN INVESTMENT IN DEVELOPING COUNTRIES: A SUMMARY OF TRENDS AND POLICY ISSUES This paper on private direct foreign investment 1/ starts with the premise that the outlines of the private investment situation are well known. In economic terms, transnational corporations are profit- maximizing, private enterprise with capital, management, technological and marketing capabilities, whose operations yield private returns. They also have social costs and benefits in their home and host countries. These depend on the "rules of the game" within which they operate, for these rules determine both private and social returns. The "rules of the game" have undergone marked changes in recent years and have changed the characteristics of private investment. New entrants--Japanese and European firms, and some from developing countries--have changed the behavior of transnationals. The paper summarizes the principal trends and policy issues in the area of private direct foreign investment. Private investment statistics are incomplete and, except in the limited DAC series, are not strictly comparable from country to country. The following is a brief summary of the principal trends, which show divergencies among countries and within the period covered. Japan and Germany have joined the United States, United Kingdom and France as important "home" countries. The share, by country, of private investment flows to developing countries out of total flows in the last decade has been about 14% for the US, 19% for the UK, nearly 30% for Germany and France, and nearly 60% for Japan. The shares of France, the UK and the US have been declining, while that of Germany has been growing. In Japan it is expected to decline in the next decade as Japan's investment in other OECD countries increases. Nearly 40% of the private investment flow from 1966 to 1976 went to Latin America and the Caribbean, a little over 25% went to Asia, mainly- to Southeast Asian countries. With respect to sectors, petroleum accounted for a third, manu- facturing nearly 40% and services such as banking that were associated with manufacturing over 20% of investment flows. Rate of Flow Real private investment flows to developing countries grew at about 4% per annum during the 1960s. Disinvestment in petroleum and other minerals was a factor. Growth accelerated to 10% per annum in the 1970s, reflecting rapid middle income country growth and the raw material boom of the early 1970s.  I. INTRODUCTION Private direct foreign investment (PDFI) in developing countries dates back to the 19th century. During the colonial and neocolonial period, it was concentrated in export-oriented mineral and agricultural production and in public utilities. Mines and plantations were enclaves with little overall impact on the growth of largely subsistence agri- cultural economies: foreign investors, often backed by their home govern- ments, appropriated most of the economic rents. As nationalist movements emerged, these investors came to be regarded as exploiters. Economic and political opposition to foreign investment was not confined to the colonial countries. There was growing opposition to investment from abroad in Canada and Australia in the 1920s and 1930s. The same was true in Europe in the 1950s, when American inflows were at their peak and European outflows were still negligible. Japan simply kept foreign investors out. Attitudes in developing countries toward private foreign investment have accordingly ranged from cautious to prohibitive. Many countries followed Mexico's pre-World War II lead and nationalized the assets of foreign corporations, particularly in mining where large rents were at issue. Public utilities were brought into the public sector to avoid exploitation of natural monopolies by private firms. However, the desire to industrialize made a new form of private investment attractive to boLh transnational corporations and developing countries. The host countries wanted to acquire technological and man- agement skills, while the corporations wanted to defend and buy into the vast new markets opened up by industrial growth. Unfortunately, the high degree of protection accorded the transnational corporations in most developing countries led to new opportunities for monopoly profits and thus further fueled opposition to foreign investors, leading to schizophrenic attitudes toward private investment in most developing countries. The transnational corporations often heightened the opposition by insisting on complete control of subsidiaries, ignoring local government directives, failing to train and promote local staff and, until the late 1960s, forbidding exports to home country or third markets by manufacturing subsidiaries. The interests of transnational corporations and of the host countries did not necessarily coincide, particularly where the "rules of the game" were highly distorted by protectionism, subsidies to capital and direct controls that favored large, 'apital-intensive plants. Given these conditions, foreign firms tended to grow at the cost of local ones. While transnational corporations themselves benefitted from investment abroad, their home countries did not necessarily do so,

This paper focuses on the principal policy issues facing transnational corporations and host and home countries in relation to private investment. It does not review the extensive literature on such investment /1 or question whether private investment per se is "good" or "bad." Rather, it assumes that private investment has costs as well as benefits resulting from the divergence between private and social benefits and the benefits accruing to various groups in a country. The starting point is that it is up to the governments of host and home countries to decide whether, and to what extent, they want to use or promote private investment as an instrument of development. It deals with the problems of private investment and the policies for overcoming them where a decision has been made to use private investment. For host country governments, the real issues are how to provide an environment in which transnational corporations can contribute to national goals while minimizing the costs and maximizing the benefits of private investment. For home country governments, the central question is how to prevent adverse effects to the home economy as a result of economic activities abroad. Both host and home countries are concerned with maximizing the benefits of an efficient international division of industrial production.' At the extreme right lies the "business-school" approach, with its implicit belief in the virtues of the free enterprise system and recommendations as to how best to minimize tax-burdens or how to plan the most profitable owner- ship strategies. The "traditional economic" approach relies on the same basic assumptions: that the freeing of international trade and capital flows is conducive both to the welfare of the world and to each country. The "neo-traditionalist" approach shares the same fundamental economic values but admits the potential divergence of interests between foreign investors and host countries and accordingly recommends remedial national and international measures. The "nationalist" approach brings the basic virtues of the international free market system into question. The "dependence" approach concludes that with foreign investment developing countries are likely to remain politically dependent and will not achieve real development. Introduction As the text indicates, the character of private direct foreign investment has been changing: from equity participation to the use of loans and suppliers' credits; from direct parent control over manage- ment to participation in management, technical agreements, production- sharing, supply contracts, etc. These changes have led the transnational corporations to shift their participation from ownership and financial contributions to technical assistance and other activities which facilitate the transfer of management, technology, etc., to host countries. The current statistical conventions clearly do not have provi- sions for these changes. To do so, statistical categories would have to be adjusted as follows: - The definition of private direct foreign investment would have to be enlarged by including the other relevant categories while maintaining equity participation (with- out floor limits) and management participation through management contracts as preconditions. Thus the private flows to enterprises would be comprised of the following two separate groups of categories: ( i) Categories presently defined as private investment: - equity participation above X percent - reinvested earnings - other short- and long-term flows from the equity investment(s) (ii) Categories which should also be included: - equity participation below X percent - reinvested earnings - other short- and long-term flows from the equity investor(s) - long-term flows from other foreign parties - export credits from third parties.

Private Direct Foreign Investment Policies Foreign Exchange Control Japan's first post-war private investment was approved in 1951. Initially, because of its balance of payments deficits, there were strict exchange controls on investment abroad. As the deficits faded away and surpluses emerged, controls have been relaxed. In October 1969, private investments of US$200,000 or less were placed under an automatic approval system by the Bank of Japan. Such invest- ments were, however, required to flow to foreign subsidiaries 25% or more of whose equity capital was owned by Japanese companies. In September 1970, the ceiling was raised to $1 million, and in July 1971, when Japan's balance of payments surpluses became a growing international concern, the ceiling was abolished, while the required rate of equity participation by Japanese companies was lowered from 25% to 10%. It is impossible to estimate how much of the support was redundant. If approvals are a guide, Japan's private investment has stagnated since FY1974. This is almost certainly largely the result of Japanese corporations' reluctance to invest, although problems in the incentive system have also contributed. Thus, while the "Foreign Currency Loan System" has mitigated the foreign exchange risks for private companies, it has burdened financial institutions with those risks. This shift in risk has apparently led them to be reluctant to lend in dollars during the period of the dollar depreciation against the yen. The JODC's upper limit of loans--in the case of minority participation, one-half of the amount of subscription--may be too low for small- and medium-sized companies. Uncertainties about the future course of the Japanese economy, however, appear to be of greater importance. Japanese companies have come to believe that Japan's high growth period, with an annual rate of 10% in real GNP, has ended, but there is no consensus yet about medium- term growth rates and the implications of reduced growth for corporate management. Consequently, these companies have become more cautious than in the high-growth period in planning expansion of their business abroad. They claim that joint ventures operate below capacity for many years and do not yield profits. The recent favorable economic conditions for Japanese companies, such as the marked acceleration of appreciation of the yen against the US dollar and monetary ease, have had only small positive effects on reviving the momentum for investment abroad. The recent level of $3 billion is likely to continue for a few years. However, some government surveys suggest that Japanese manufacturing industries have a strong investment potential, and private investment is expected to increase again fairly rapidly in the 1980's. Investment in developing countries is likely to center on natural re- sources-related investments including oil refineries and petrochemicals, and on iron and steel.

doc.repnme: Private direct foreign investment in developing countries
doc.abstracts: The paper discusses the changing characteristics of private direct foreign investment in developing countries in relation to home and host country policies. An overall view of the geographical and sectoral characteristics of private direct foreign investment flows to developing countries introduces the paper. The response of the transnational corporations to the changing environment in developing countries is then discussed. The mainbody of the paper is concerned with policy issues for the developing countries that wish to attract private direct foreign investment and for the industrialized countries that are the principal source of such flows. The authors conclude that overall macroeconomic and sectoral policies are of overwhelming policy importance, but also explore incentive policies and some institutional issues. A discussion of the role of international institutions in the private investment environment concludes the paper.
